Lior, 

This is very interesting. Do you have any cites for this claim that=
 replication for Eukaryotes is completely independent of genome size? I'd b=
e interested in reading those papers. 


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

oral Fellow
Cornell University

On Nov =
12, 2011, at 8:00 PM, lior_fainshil wrote:

> This actually happens in natu=
re. In bacteria the DNA is replicated serially and the reproduction time is=
 proportional to DNA length. Eukaryotes on the other hand, have a parallel =
DNA replication mechanism and reproduction time is independent of DNA lengt=
h. This produced wildly different results in DNA content. Most bacteria hav=
e very lean genomes. In eukaryotes on other hand, most of the DNA holds var=
ious forms of junk. A striking example of this is an amoeba having 200 time=
s the DNA length of a human. Eukaryotes, of course, got way more sophistica=
ted than bacteria. There are too many other variables here however for us t=
o put it down to the lack of complexity penalty.
> 
>
